fields.title: Everest View Trekking
fields.description: As compared to other trekking routes in the Everest Region, Everest view trekking is relatively easy and short as well as very spectacular. This trek takes you to introduce mountain villages, Sherpa people and their culture along with great views
fields.include:
Airport pick up and transfer to hotel

4 nights' accommodation in Kathmandu

Breakfast and accommodation on trek

All necessary paper works and Sagarmatha National Park entry permit

All accommodations in lodges/tea houses during the trek.

Trekkers’ Information Management System (TIMS) Permit.

An experienced, helpful, friendly and English speaking trekking Guide

Necessary porters (1 porter for 2 people) each porter carries 30 kg

Salary, Food, Drinks, Accommodation, domestic flight & Insurance of our trekking guide

Salary, Food, Drinks, Accommodation, and Insurance for porters from Lukla

Travel, medical & emergency rescue by helicopter (need to pay by your insurance)

Arrangement of Helicopter service for rescue in case of emergency in the mountain (the cost incurred during the rescue will be paid by your insurance company)

Extra night accommodation in Kathmandu because of early return from the trekking (due to any reason)

Expenses of personal nature such as laundry, telephone, bar bills, tips, battery recharge, extra porters, bottle or boiled water, shower etc

Tips & Gratuities for trekking guide & porter (s)
fields.content:
As compared to other trekking routes in the Everest Region, Everest view trekking is relatively easy and short as well as very spectacular. This trek takes you to introduce mountain villages, Sherpa people and their culture along with great views of world’s highest mountains including Mt. Everest.

Everest view trekking starts with a half an hour mountain flight from Kathmandu to Lukla. After you land at Lukla airstrip you begin trek heading to Phakding where you spend the first overnight in the mountain.. Next day morning you walk following Dudha Koshi River and then gently climb forests of rhododendron and magnolia and arrive at Namche Bazaar, a bustling Bazaar (market), a junction for trekkers. Here, at Namche Bazaar you spend one more extra day for acclimatization and excursion. On the rest day you make excursion to Syangboche, one of the major spots for the view of Mt. Everest, Mt. Lhotse, Mt. Ama Dablam, Mt. Thamserku, Mt.Kangtega, Kwangde etc. Then, you walk down to Khumjung village, a typical Sherpa village.

Sherpa are ethnic people of Everest region. Lots of the world renowned climbers such as Tenzing Norgay Sherpa, Apa Sherpa and many other climbers belong to this ethnic community. In Khumjung you meet local people, experience their lifestyle. Visiting Khumjung Monastery makes your walking more worthwhile. Next day you trek to Tengboche where a famous Sherpa Buddhist Monastery is located. In Tengboche you will meet Buddhist monks and see their daily rituals inside the Monastery. Tengboche is the final destination of Everest View Trekking. From here you return to Lukla via Namche Bazaar and take a flight back to Kathmandu.

Everest View Trekking is ideal for older, family with children those people who desire to see world’s high mountains including Mt. Everest within short days. Everest Panorama trek is also known by Everest Panorama Trek following the same itinerary and duration. This is a real holiday trekking you will ever remember in your lifetime.

fields.title: Annapurna Sanctuary Trekking
fields.description: Annapurna Sanctuary Trekking is a picturesque walking journey that takes you to the foothills of the Annapurna South. It is also popularly called Annapurna Base Camp Trekking. Trekking to Annapurna Sanctuary is highly recommended for those who love to explore

Airport pick up and transfer to hotel

English speaking local trekking guide

13% VAT and service charge

Emergency rescue evacuation if needed (need to pay by your insurance)

Extra night accommodation in Kathmandu because of early return from the trekking (due to any reason)

Tips & Gratuities for trekking guide & porter (s)
fields.content:
Annapurna Sanctuary Trekking is a picturesque walking journey that takes you to the foothills of the Annapurna South. It is also popularly called Annapurna Base Camp Trekking. Trekking to Annapurna Sanctuary is highly recommended for those who love to explore the rich cultural diversities, typical Nepalese villages, enjoy the flora and fauna and immerse in the panoramic view of Annapurna, Dhaulagiri Himalayan range.

The journey to the Annapurna Sanctuary kicks off from Pokhara with a one-hour drive to Nayapul. From Nayapul we trek to Tikhedhunga (1540m.) passing through terraced fields of potatoes, mustard, corn and vegetables, past small villages of stone-built houses and then, higher altitude, through forests of bamboo and of flowering rhododendrons until you reach glaciated terrain. While on trek we enjoy outstanding Himalayan mountain views in the distance. From Chhomrong, we walk up the Modi Khola gorge which takes us into the heart of the sanctuary and some of the most dramatic mountain scenery on the planet. 

Walking slowly and steadily you walk through Machhapuchare base camp and ultimately reach at Base Camp of Annapurna South. The huge south face of Annapurna (8090 m.) provides an impressive backdrop, while the up close views of towering peaks over 6000 m. inspires a joy and lifetime experience for every trekker. With superb views of Mt. Machhapuchhre, Annapurna South and Hiunchuli in the backdrop, the base camp is a great place to spend one or two days. 

The extraordinary variety of ecosystem is compressed into two weeks of Annapurna Base Camp walking. The Annapurna south facing slope of the base camp is covered with dense of tropical jungle of rhododendron and bamboo. On the other hand, the alpine region above 3000 m in the north offers dry rain shadow area with colder climate similar to the Tibetan plateau. We return to Phedi via Dhampus (1650m.) and catch our vehicle for Pokhara. This area is well developed with lodge facilities.

fields.title: Everest Base Camp Trekking
fields.description: Everest Base Camp Trekking is one of the most adventurous and exciting treks that take you to the base of Everest- the world’s highest mountain. This trekking has been listed as “World’s Best Hikes out of 20 Dream Trails” by

fields.content:
Everest Base Camp Trekking is one of the most adventurous and exciting treks that take you to the base of Everest- the world’s highest mountain. This trekking has been listed as “World’s Best Hikes out of 20 Dream Trails” by National Geographic.

The mountain scenery of the Everest region is incredibly beautiful. You will walk through multi-hued prayer flags, prayer wheels and intricately carved Mani stones dotted every hilltop and rockwalls. You can see prayer flags fluttering in the air either at the trail side or nearby Sherpa villages. While on the trek you will also experience Sherpa culture, their traditional lifestyle and hospitality. You will stop at numerous teahouses, sip a glass of sweetened tea or Chang (millet beer) and get a taste of hospitality of the Sherpa community. You will also visit Buddhist monasteries on the way and learn about how Lamaistic Buddhism influences Sherpas life. Everest Base Camp trekking begins with an exciting flight to Lukla at 2840 meters and then you begin mountain journey through the picturesque Sherpa villages from Phakding to Gorakshep (5140m.) via Namche Bazaar, eventually culminating in the "ascent" of Kala Pattar (5545m.). From Kala Pattar, the highest point of the trek, you will enjoy classic views of Mt. Everest, Mt. Lhotse, Mt. Nuptse Mt. Makalu, Mt. Cho Oyo, Mt Ama Dablam, Mt. Cholatse, Mt. Kangtega, Mt. Thamserku, and many other summits. Most of the time you will walk above altitudes of 3000 meters in the Khumbu and Imja valleys, whose skylines are dominated by the massive peaks of the Eastern Himalayas. In April- May the rhododendrons are seen in full blooming with orchids growing all along the trails in and around the Sagarmatha National Park. Trek to Everest Base Camp does not require you to be an athlete or experienced hiker and climber. Anyone in good physical fitness and who exercises on a regular basis can comfortably and safely complete this trekking. However, you have to make difficult and sometimes long days walking to Base Camp and hiking up Kala Pattar but you have to make a slow and steady pace of walk.

fields.title: Gokyo - Chola Pass & Everest Base Camp Trekking
fields.description: Gokyo - Chola Pass & Everest Base Camp Trekking is one of the most adventurous and challenging trek in the Everest Region. It follows the route via high pass called Chola Pass at 5420 meters into Mt. Everest Base Camp

Tips & Gratuities for trekking guide & porter (s)
fields.content:
Gokyo - Chola Pass & Everest Base Camp Trekking is one of the most adventurous and challenging trek in the Everest Region. It follows the route via high pass called Chola Pass at 5420 meters into Mt. Everest Base Camp (5364m.). Trekking to Gokyo - Chola Pass & Everest Base Camp begins with an amazing flight to Lukla. From Lukla you will walk uphill slowly following the trail to the Dudh Kosi (it means ‘River of Milk’), and all through forests of rhododendron, pine and magnolia. After few hours of trekking you will eventually reach Namche Bazaar (3,340 m) and spend one more day at Namche Bazaar (the delightful Sherpa capital) for acclimatization and optional hike around. From Namche you will visit other Sherpa villages such as Phortse Tanga and Machhermo before heading for Gokyo Lake. After you reach Gokyo Lake you climb Gokyo Ri (5369m.) and from the top of Gokyo Ri you will enjoy stunning peaks of different mountains such as Mt. Everest, Mt. Lhotse, Mt. Nuptse Mt. Makalu, Mt. Cho Oyo, Mt Ama Dablam, Mt. Cholatse, Mt. Kangtega, Mt. Thamserku, and many others. Then, next day you cross Chola Pass (5420m.) and reach at Dzongla. After Dzongla you move towards Gorakshep and ascend to Kala Pattar (5545m.). From Kala Pattar you enjoy an impressive up-close view of Mt. Everest. Then, next day morning you trek to Everest Base Camp. When you return from Everest Base Camp you follow the route through Pangboche and Namche Bazaar. While on trek you will enjoy the incredible mountain scenery until you reach Lukla airstrip. Next day morning you take a flight back to Kathmandu. 

Gokyo - Chola Pass & Everest Base Camp Trekking is popular for every traveler and group alike. It gives a complete scenario of different flora and fauna, rural lifestyle of the Sherpa people, Buddhism, monasteries and spectacular mountain scenery.
fields.titles: Gokyo - Chola Pass & Everest Base Camp Trekking

fields.title: Annapurna Full Circuit Trekking
fields.description: Annapurna Circuit trekking is a classic 150-mile long trek that encircles the entire Annapurna massif and fills with stunning views of Annapurna Himalayan range consisting of Annapurna, Machhapuchhre, and Nilgiri, the Dhaulagiri Mountain Range and the Manaslu Mountain Range. En

fields.content:
Annapurna Circuit trekking is a classic 150-mile long trek that encircles the entire Annapurna massif and fills with stunning views of Annapurna Himalayan range consisting of Annapurna, Machhapuchhre, and Nilgiri, the Dhaulagiri Mountain Range and the Manaslu Mountain Range.

En route we pass through spectacular settlements inhabited by diverse ethnic group of people and landscapes from lowland farming country to alpine meadows to the Tibet-like country on the northern slopes of the Himalaya. We start in the foothills at Besi Sahar and reach after 6 days to the settlement of Manang at 3500m where we acclimatise and enjoy the mountain views. No place anywhere in Nepal looks similar to Mustangs’ landscape .It lies behind the Annapurna range in rain shadow area which blocks the rain and is desert like landscape. From Manang we continue to ascend slowly and on day 10 of the trek we cross the famous Thorung La, at 5416m, and head for Muktinath, an important pilgrimage site for Hindus and Buddhists. Crossing Thorang La pass is technically easy and wonderful experience. After crossing Thorang La pass we make easy but long descend into the Kali Gandaki river valley, with Annapurna and Dhaulagiri towering on either side.Then, we visit Muktinath. If you are religiously inclined, you can take a bath in 108 taps and 2 ponds in the temple premises to relieve yourself of all your sins as per the sayings of Hindu religion.

Further down we visit Tatopani where we take bath at hot natural springs and relax. Then, we climb up Poon Hill, above Ghorepani, to enjoy magnificent mountain views. En route back to Pokhara we pass through many beautiful Gurung villages that populate this ancient trading route between Tibet and India. Accommodation and food is provided in the local lodges along the trail. Transport to Besi Sahar is by local or private coach depending on the travel plan and the return to Kathmandu from Pokhara is by road.

fields.description: Ghorepani Poon Hill Trek is one of the shortest and most popular cultural treks to experience culture and lifestyle of the Gurung communities in the Annapurna region. The trail leads us through beautiful sub tropical valleys, dense forests of rhododendron

fields.content:
Ghorepani Poon Hill Trek is one of the shortest and most popular cultural treks to experience culture and lifestyle of the Gurung communities in the Annapurna region. The trail leads us through beautiful sub tropical valleys, dense forests of rhododendron and icy waterfalls. We can view around every corner during the trek soaring Himalayan peaks such as Mt. Dhaulagiri (8,167m.), Mt. Annapurna I (8,091m.), Mt. Machapurhre (Fish Tail) (6993m), Mt. Tukuche (6920m), Mt. Nilgiri ( 6940m), Mt. Hiunchuli (6441m), Mt. Annapurna South (7219m), Mt. Lamjung Himal (6931m) and some other many smaller peaks during the trip. From Poon Hill (3210m.) we can see the best view of sunrise and Himalayan mountain range early in the morning. This entire trekking area is mainly dominated by the Gurungs and Magars both are ethnic people of Nepal. Dense Rhododendron forests, varieties of bird species, deep sub-tropical valleys, traditional villages, age-old tradition and culture, hospitable people, ever-smiling faces of the people, majestic mountain views are the major attractions of this trek.

Ghandruk village provides an insight into the lifestyles of Gurung ethnic community of Nepal. Here, you will see how orderly rows of neat slate- roofed houses are clustered on the canyon wall amidst a complicated network of farming terraces. In addition, you will enjoy with great views of Himalayas that includes Macchapuchre (Fishtail) and Annapurna South. From Pokhara it is just 42 kilometers drive and 5–6 hours in walking distance. Pothana is another popular village where you will also encounter same Gurung ethnic community like in the Ghandruk village. This village is situated on the ridge of hill from where you can enjoy the spectacular view of Annapurna Himalayan range, Fishtail and green valley of Pokhara.

Simplytour.com can make the itinerary shorter without including Ghandruk village as per client’s requirements. Those who have longer holiday can go via Ghandruk and end the trek in Pokhara. And, those who have short holiday and prefer to trek only up to Ghorepani and end the trek in Dhampus Phedi is also possible. We recommend Ghorepani-Poon Hill and Ghandruk trek because on this route you will enjoy the best panoramic Mountain View, experience Gurung culture and lifestyle and make a circuit.

fields.content:
Langtang is considered Nepal's third most popular trekking region after Annapurna and Everest. Trek to Langtang and Gosainkund takes you straight into some of the wildest and most picturesque areas of Nepal. Starting from the lovely hill town of Syabrubensi, you will trek through beautiful and conifer forests of the Langtang National Park towards the higher altitude.

In the spring, the entire trekking route looks like a natural garden of wild colorful flowers. First you will reach the Langtang valley and then walk over the high alpine yak pastures, glaciers and moraines around Kyangin and trek further up the Sacred Lake of Gosainkund (4380 m). The areaaround Lake Gosainkund is most of the time enveloped in mist, and on clear weather we can see beautiful mountains to the north. In the winter the lake remains frozen. Here, you will find peace and serene environment. Gosainkund is sacred for both Hindus and Buddhist, and every full moon day in the month of August many visitors throng to celebrate the Gosainkund festival. From Gosainkund you will enjoy panoramic views of snow-clad mountains extended as far as Annapurna Himalayan Range. The large black rock in the middle of the Gosainkund Lake is regarded as remains of Shiva and it is believed that the waters of the lake flow through the underground channel to the water basin of Khumbheshwar temple in Patan. At this higher altitude, the terrain transforms to arid alpine above tree line and the population gets sparser. Crossing Laurabina Yak La Pass at (4,615m), adjoining the Gosainkund and Helambu regions is another challenge for the adventure enthusiasts. During the Langtang and Gosainkund trekking you will have an opportunity to explore the whole range of Himalayan topography, ethnic culture and lifestyle of the local people. Besides, you will also have a chance to see some interesting animals and birds at the side of trails. Among those found in the Langtang National Park are monkeys, musk deer, pika and the national bird of Nepal, the colourful pheasant.

fields.description: Langtang Valley lies just north of Kathmandu between the main Himalayan ranges and a slightly lower range of snowy peaks south of the Tibetan border. Trekking to Langtang valley takes us into high alpine yak pastures, glaciers and moraines around

fields.content:
Langtang Valley lies just north of Kathmandu between the main Himalayan ranges and a slightly lower range of snowy peaks south of the Tibetan border. Trekking to Langtang valley takes us into high alpine yak pastures, glaciers and moraines around Kyanjing Gompa and offers us an opportunity to explore ethnic villages and diverse flora and fauna. In the Langtang valley you will find a small settlement of Sherpa people whereas the lower part of the valley such as Dhunche, Bharkhu and Syabru are mainly inhabited by Tamang ethnic group of people. Both these ethnic groups of people follow Buddhism and practice their respective culture and tradition. They earn their livelihood herding yak, sheep and producing buckwheat, potatoes, wheat and barley in the fields. Their houses are made of stones and wood covered with flat zinc roof that has tons of stone placed on top to secure them from flying.

According to legend, the Langtang valley was discovered by one Buddhist monk following a runaway yaks. This is how the name-Langtang word is derived, Lang means Yak and tang means to follow. Langtang Valley Trek can be completed in 9 days starts and ends in Kathmandu. We begin the trek from Dhunche heading uphill to Lama Hotel and Langtang village until we arrive at the famous Kyanjing Gompa. Here, you will find Yaks everywhere. The view of Langtang Lirung and its glacier is beautiful. En route you will pass by the cheese factory and the ancient  old monastery. From Kyanjing Gompa you can hike early in the morning up to Kyanjing Ri (4773m) and enjoy the view of the Langtang Lirung becoming orange and slowly turn to white. After exploring the Langtang valley, we retrace the same route to Syabrubesi from where we catch a transport and drive back to Kathmandu. Langtang Valley Trekking is a highly recommended medium- hard trek that can be arranged throughout the year. Simplytour.com organize all tours and treks all over Nepal according to the clients' interest, time and budget.

fields.content:
Chitwan, thrilling destination to feel the wildlife adventure of different kind ­ Jungle Safari,Elephant Bathing, Boating, Chepang Hill , Bird watching and lots more.

JUNGLE SAFARI

The most thrilling taste of nature can be felt during the jungle safari and the chances to see animals in their natural habitat. Chitwan National Park, one of the Asia’s finest place to observe 56 species of mammals, 49 species of amphibians and reptiles, and 525 species of birds. Rare birds of world can be witnessed in National park territory. Many endangered species like the one­horned rhinoceros, the Royal Bengal tiger, wild elephant, four­horned antelope, leopard, sloth bear, wild boar, , grey langur monkey, and many other smaller animals can be seen here at Chitwan National Park.

ELEPHANT BATHING

Elephant bathing is next adventurous thing that should not be missed in Chitwan. Elephant loves bathing and splashing water over the people riding on its back. Its truly natural experience to feel.

BOATING

It is fun filled journey to visit those place where there are no roads to access the beauty. Many visitors said that it is a package of excitement.

CHEPANG HILL

Chepang hill trek, is short trek which delivers magnificent views of the mountains and glorious sunrise and sunset views. When the weather is clear you can see the views include a range of Himalayan peaks such as Rolwaling, Dorje Lakpa, Gaurishankar, Langtang, Manaslu Range, Himalchuli, Annapurna range, Dhaulagiri rare view flatland and spectacular sunrise and sunsets can be clearly observed cultural experiences of chepang and other ethnic groups.

BIRD WATCHING

The most popular place to watch rare bird is in Chitwan itself. There are more than 500 species of bird. The innocent face of birds and their pleasing sound makes smile on visitors’ face. Photographer may capture the untamed beauty of birds.

Beauty lies in experiencing rather than explaining.

Nepal is the only country in the modern world that does not have a rectangular national flag, consisting of two united pennant (triangular flag) shapes. It is crimson with blue borders and incorporates stylized symbols of the sun and moon. The blue border on the flag of Nepal signifies peace and harmony, whereas crimson color signifies victory and bravery; the color of rhododendron(the national flower of Nepal). It is said that the national flag of Nepal anticipates that the nation will last as long as the sun and moon is there on earth. 

The moon represents the serenity of the Nepalese people and the cool weather in the Himalayas. It also symbolizes the longevity of the kingdom. Likewise, the sun represents the fierce persistence of the Nepalese people and the heat of the lower parts of Nepal. It also symbolizes the perpetuity of the kingdom. Until 1962, the flag’s emblems, the sun and the crescent moon, had human faces. The faces were removed in order to modernize the flag. The faces remained on the sun and the moon on the Royal Standard until the abolition of the monarchy in 2008. The flag was adopted, with the formation of a new constitutional government, on December 16, 1962. The individual pennants had been used for the preceding two centuries and the double pennant since the 19th century. Flag of Nepal is also known as most mathematically calculated flag ever and its written in the constitution, which describes how it is constructed.

Mount Everest (8848ft), highest peak in the world, is also known as Chomolungma in Tibetan language and Sagarmatha in Nepali language. It is located at Solukhumbu district in the range of Mahalangur Himal, the great Himalayas. Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay were the first to scale the mountain in 1953. It has been climbed for more than 5,600 times

Before climbing any mountain, weather and snow conditions should be at higher priority, in such case experienced guide will help to forecast the overall conditions of that particular camp area. Everest Base Camp (EBC), which basically has traditional infrastructure like: Kitchen/Dining Tent, Sleeping Tent and Toilet Tent.

The favorable season to climb Mt. Everest is the end of September through December. During this period the weather tends to be relatively stable with mild to warm days and cold nights. Mid October to November is a good time to get breathtaking views of the peak with calm and clear weather. May, June, September, and October are moderate time to travel to Mt. Everest.Photographers may prefer April, as it is the best time to capture the flag­like cloud floating above the peak..

People have always wondered what it feels like to fly like a bird. Paragliding can give you a wonderful flying experience. It is unique, simplest and adventurous sports that offers excitement, relaxation for adventure­seekers.

Paragliding in Nepal gives a breath­taking experience of pleasant and fantastic view of majestic Himalayan including Annapurna and Dhaulagiri ranges while sharing the space in the air with Himalayan griffin vultures, kites and eagle.Thrilling view of the temple(Tal Barahi) situated in between the Fewa lake is breath taking . The famous place for paragliding in Nepal is the hilltop of Sarangkot (1592m) from where the gliding takes off and lands in the open space beside the Fewa lake giving the opportunity of observing beautiful landscapes of Pokhara Valley, the mesmerizing Fewa lake, Machhapuchhre himal(Fishtail), Annapurna Himal. Himchuli, the Peace Pagoda and greenaries around the lake.

Paragliding depends upon the weather condition. The favourable time for paragliding in Nepal begins at September and ends in February during which, the weather is cool with clear visibility. During this period, a clear view of Himalayas and beautiful sceneries can be observed.

It is lightweight, free­flying, foot­launched glider aircraft. Paragliding in Nepal gives a breath­taking experience of pleasant and fantastic view of majestic Himalayan including Annapurna and Dhaulagiri ranges while sharing the space in the air with Himalayan griffin vultures, kites and eagle.Thrilling view of the temple(Tal Barahi) situated in between the Fewa lake is breath taking . The famous place for paragliding in Nepal is the hilltop of Sarangkot (1592m) from where the gliding takes off and lands in the open space beside the Fewa lake giving the opportunity of observing beautiful landscapes of Pokhara Valley, the mesmerizing Fewa lake, Machhapuchhre himal(Fishtail), Annapurna Himal. Himchuli, the Peace Pagoda and greenaries around the lake.

There are many places to visit in Nepal. Pokhara is one of the most exciting and adventurous place and is also known as piece of a heaven in earth. Pokhara, surrounded by different Himalayan Ranges, commits the visitors with many unbelievable sceneries and adds up the value in their experience by providing different remarkable places.

Fewa Taal:

Fewa taal, second largest lake in kingdom, is the center of attraction of Pokhara. The bank of this lake is covered with the numbers of brightly colored wooden boats which are available for renting giving an opportunity to explore the lake. The eastern part of this lake, also known as lakeside, contains several hotels, lodges, restaurants and different souvenir shops. The lakeside provides the magnificent view of mountain. Also, the island in the middle of the lake enhances the glory of Fewa Taal.

Barahi Temple:

The Barahi temple, situated in the middle of the Fewa lake, is considered as the most important monument in Pokhara. It is the 2­storied pagoda dedicated to Ajima in the boar manifestation and the representing the the force of Shakti(the mother of goddess). Worshipers can be seen making their way carrying male animals for sacrifice especially on Saturdays,. The way to reach this temple is by hiring the boats from the bank of the Fewa lake.

World Peace Pagoda:

World Peace Pagoda, balanced on a narrow ridge of the Fewa lake, is Buddhist Stupa presenting an impressive sight. It is a great vantage point for the viewers which offers remarkable view of Pokhara and Annapurna Ranges.

David’s Fall:

David’s Fall, also known as Patale Chhango(Hell’s fall), is an amazing waterfall that creates the sound of the water plunging over the falls. It was named Devi’s Fall as according to local legends, a Swiss visitor, named David, tumbled into the sinkhole and drowned. It is situated about 2 km south­west of Pokhara airport on the way of Tansen, Butwal.

Gupteshwor Gupha, Mahendra Gupha and Chamero Gupha:

Gupteshwor Gupha(cave) is situated just opposite to David’s Fall. The cave is 3 km long with some passages where you have to crawl your way out. Lying 2 km south­west of the Pokhara airport, it holds special value in Hindu culture since the phallic symbol of Lord Shiva is preserved in the condition it was discovered. At the end of the cave, the sight of the waterfall will dazzle the spectators.

Mahendra Gupha(cave) is one of the most popular visiting spot in Pokhara. It is located at the northern part of Pokhara. There are many transportation that can be found to get to this caves. Guides are available to guide through the caves. Chamero Gupha(cave), known as Chamero Odhaar(house of bats), is located near to Mahendra cave with thousands of bats hanging from the ceiling of the cave. Guides are not required for exploring the cave but some guidance can be taken to come out from the other side of the cave.

Souvenir gives the essence of the beauty of the country. Still confused what to buy attractive souvenir in Nepal? Then, this will help you to select the best one among different alternatives.

1. Thankas:

It is pronounced as tangka, thanka or tanka, is a Tibetan Buddhist painting on cotton, or silk applique, usually depicting a Buddhist deity, scene, or mandala.


2. Prayer Flag:

It is a colorful rectangular cloth available in five different colors; Green, Blue, White, Red and Yellow, often found strung along mountain ridges and peaks high in the Himalayas.


3. Khukuri:

It is a characteristic weapon of the Nepalese Army, the Royal Gurkha Rifles and of all Gurkha brigade throughout the world, so much so that some English­speakers refer to the weapon as a "Gurkha blade" or "Gurkha knife".


4. Dhaka Topi:

It is a traditional Nepali hat worn in special occasion like; Marriage and others.


5. Pashmina:

It is made from the inner soft wool of goat, which is a special breed of native goat found in high altitudes of the Himalayas in Nepal.


“The souvenir will make your relatives feel special and the memory will always be in your heart.”

SHERPA, are courageous and dedicated people who first settled in the Solukhumbu District (Khumbu), Nepal ;then they gradually moved westward along salt trade routes. Looking back at the history, Khumbu Sherpa people accomplish autonomy within the newly formed Nepali state. In the 1960s, as tension with China increased, Nepali government influence on the Sherpa people grew.

The bright smiles and remarkable strength of the Sherpas have been an intrinsic part of Everest climbing expeditions from the very beginning. The strength of Sherpas have amazed many visitors. They are well­suited for high­altitude climbing and apparently resistant to cold. 

Some great Sherpas:

Tenzing Norgay Sherpa

Tenzing Norgay was born in Tshechu, presently in Tibet Autonomous Region, China. He grew up in peasant family in Khumbu in Nepal. He was a Nepalese Sherpa mountaineer. He was remembered by creating the history on May 29, 1953, when he and Sir Edmund Hillary became the first men to conquer Mount Everest. 

Apa Sherpa

Apa Sherpa, who was born on 20 January 1960, nicknamed "Super Sherpa", is a Nepalese Sherpa mountaineer who, jointly with Phurba Tashi, holds the record for reaching the summit of Mount Everest more times than any other person. As part of The Eco Everest Expedition 2011, Apa made his 21st Mount Everest summit in May 2011.

Pasang Lhamu Sherpa

Pasang Lhamu Sherpa, who was born into a mountaineering family and was involved in climbing from her teens. She was the first Nepali woman to reach the summit of Mt. Everest, on April 22,1993. She had successfully climbed Mont Blanc, Cho Oyu, Mount Yala peak, Pisang Himal, and many others.

Sherpas are the pride to the nation with remarkable strength and bravery

Pokhara is an amazing and one of the most beautiful city. All the people who visit Nepal can’t resist to visit this city of natural beauty. There are many things to do. And from those there are some of the things that shouldn’t be miss while visiting Pokhara.

Top 5 Things To Do in Pokhara

Paragliding :

One thing a person can’t do is fly. Paragliding give you that experience. Flying above the earth surface viewing the majestic Himalayas, lakes, monasteries, temples and the greenery surrounding the lake is an indescribable experience that no one could forget. Sarangkot is the famous location for paragliding, from where the view of the beautiful Machhapuchhre Himal(Fishtail) and the mesmerizing Fewa lake can be seen. 

Ultra­lights:

The next thing you don’t wanna miss is the Ultra­lights. It is an aircraft that flies at the maximum height of 5000m giving you breathtaking view of entire Pokhara Valley. It is a two seated aircraft that are operated from Pokhara airport. They can take off and land on dirt road or on the field. It adds new perspective in exploring Annapurna and Dhaulagiri Ranges for an hour or more.

Boating:

Boating is one of the famous things to do in Pokhara. Boating in fewa taal with the flow of air touching your body and the sound of water flowing gives you an amazing experience. The small island in the middle of Fewa Taal that provide shelter for the temple known as “Taal Barahi” enhances your experience of boating. The other two lakes, Begnas Taal and Rupa Taal, also provide the service of boating. Boating can be done by hiring the boats for an hour or for a whole day. The best way for boating experience is to rent the boat without the boatman and going on the adventurous journey all by yourself. You can also visit different beautiful places and places filled with greenery where there is no access of road. Winter season, from October to February, is the best period for boating as the skies are clear, the mountains, covered with snow, cast their shadow on the lake’s calm water.

Golf:

Nepal is not only rich in Cultural heritage but it offers some finest golf courses in South Africa. There are 2 golf courses in Pokhara, they are: Himalayan Golf Club and Fulbari Resort Golf Course that offers the excellent golf course with magnificent view of Himalayas. the sports lover can enjoy the playing golf with other facilities like spa and ayurvedic treatments.

Sightseeing:

Sightseeing the city is one of the greatest eye candy of all. One can go on a boat tour of Phewa Lake with magnificent Barahi Temple at the heart of it. The Devi's Fall and the Hindu shrine at Gupteshor Mahadev Cave give a fascinating experience of all time. Buying souvenir in the Old Bazaar and exploring the world of mountaineering at the Mountain Museum is a great way of spending more of the time in Pokhara. Not to forget the Seti Gandaki Gorge with a spectacular views of the Himalayas.
